com.lonepulse.robozombie
Interface GenericFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT,FAILURE extends Throwable>

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractGenericFactory, ProcessorChainFactory
public interface GenericFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT,FAILURE extends Throwable>

This contract specifies a generic policy for a factory. Its takes the raw materials specified by INPUT to manufacture an object of the type OUTPUT and expects a Throwable of type FAILURE to be thrown in case of a manufacturing error.

Use this contract when different factories may be passed to a dependent object, where the factories produce an OUTPUT which adheres to a contract or super-type and yet differ in implementation or extended-type based on the provided concrete factory. The same can be said for the INPUT and FAILURE types as well.

Since:
1.3.0

Version:
1.2.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

Method Detail

newInstance

OUTPUT newInstance()
                   throws FAILURE extends Throwable

Manufactures a new instance of the OUTPUT without any INPUT. This method could be used to create the entity with its default components and properties. Such details must be clearly documented in the implementation.

Returns:
a new instance of the INPUT

Throws:
the - type of FAILURE to expect from a manufacturing error

FAILURE extends Throwable
Since:
1.3.0

newInstance

OUTPUT newInstance(Map<String,INPUT> inputMap)
                   throws FAILURE extends Throwable

Takes a Map of raw materials (keyed by Strings) as the INPUT and manufactures the INPUT. All implementations must check for the existence of the INPUT and validate it before proceeding with the manufacture.

Parameters:
inputMap - the INPUT Map whose entries are used to manufacture the INPUT

Returns:
a new instance of the INPUT

Throws:
the - type of FAILURE to expect from a manufacturing error

FAILURE extends Throwable
Since:
1.3.0

newInstance

OUTPUT newInstance(INPUT input,
                   INPUT... inputs)
                   throws FAILURE extends Throwable

Takes a single INPUT as an essential raw material to manufacture the INPUT and produces a new instance of it. It may take additional INPUTs which are required for the manufacturing process. All implementations must check for the existence of the essential INPUT and validate it before proceeding with the manufacture.

Parameters:
input - an INPUT which is essential to the manufacture of the INPUT without which the manufacturing process will fail

inputs - further INPUTs which can be used in the manufacturing of the INPUT but are not essential to the process

Returns:
a new instance of the INPUT

Throws:
the - type of FAILURE to expect from a manufacturing error

FAILURE extends Throwable
Since:
1.3.0
